dataset.title: Soil N2O and NO emissions from an arid, urban ecosystem in central Arizona-Phoenix

creator.organizationName: School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University
School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University

abstract.para: Soil nitrogen (N) cycling and fluxes of N2O and NO in three land-use types across the metropolitan area of Phoenix, Arizona has been measured.Urbanization increased N2O emissions compared to native landscapes, primarily due to the expansion of fertilized and irrigated lawns. Fluxes of N2O from lawns ranged from 18 to 80 mg N m^(-2) h^(-1) and were significantly larger than managed xeric landscapes (2.5-22 mg N m^(-2) h^(-1)) and remnant desert sites within the urban core (3.7-14 mg N m^(-2) h^(-1)). In contrast, average NO fluxes from lawns were not significantly different from native desert when dry (6-80 mg N m^(-2) h^(-1); 5-16 mg N m^(-2) h^(-1) desert) and were lower than fluxes from deserts after wetting events. Furthermore, urbanization has significantly altered the temporal dynamics of NO emissions by replacing pulse-driven desert ecosystems with year-round irrigated, managed lawns. Short-term, pulse-driven emissions of NO from wetting of dry desert soils may reach 35% of anthropogenic emissions within a day after summer monsoon storms. If regional O3 production is NOx-limited during the monsoon season, fluxes from warm, recently wet arid soils may contribute to summer O3 episodes. .

section.title: Background and Postwatering Soil N Cycling and Gas Fluxes
section.para: 1. Background soil N cycling and N oxide emissions from replicate sites of lawns, managed xeric landscapes, and remnant Sonoran Desert sites within the urban airshed were measured.
2. All background measurements were taken between 1100 and 1700 LT to minimize temperature differences between sites.
3. To assess the effects of rainfall, gas emissions at all sites before and 2-3 h after a simulated 5 mm rainstorm were measured.
4. Rain was simulated by sprinkling 500 mL of deionized water (in 2001) or water with 0.1N MgCl (in 2006, to simulate the electrical conductivity of rainfall) evenly over the measurement area. .
5. Prior to watering, five soil cores (0-10 cm) randomly across each plot were collected.

section.title: Gas Collection and Analysis
section.para: 1. Soil N2O was measured using a closed chamber technique.
2. Four beveled PVC rings were inserted several cm into the soil at random locations in each site.
3. Molded PVC chambers were placed over each ring, and air was sampled from the chamber four times over a 30-min period.
4. Twenty milliliters of chamber air were collected in plastic syringes and immediately placed in preevacuated, silicone-sealed, 10 mL glass Wheaton vials with inert stoppers.
5. Samples and certified N2O standards were collected and treated in the same way. Samples were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC) fitted with an electron capture detector.
6. Gas fluxes were calculated as the increase in concentration within each chamber over a 30-min period corrected for chamber volume and air temperature.

7. Nitric oxide was measured in situ at each site within 1 h of N2O measurements within a Teflon-coated, white, opaque soil chamber using a portable chemiluminescent detector (LMA-3 in 2001 and LMA-3D in 2006, Unisearch Associates, Ltd., Canada) fitted with a CrO3 filter that converts all NO to NO2.
8. The custom-made chamber top was fitted to each of the PVC rings immediately before or after measurement of N2O fluxes.
9. Nitrogen dioxide concentrations were estimated photochemically after their reaction with Luminol II solution.

10. To eliminate inference of humid air coming from soil surface, we ran the LMA-3 at a 5:1 ratio of dry ambient air (scrubbed free of water vapor with anhydrous calcium sulfate) to chamber air according to methods developed for this instrument in [Davidson et al., 1991; Matson et al., 1996].

11. In order to correct all chamber fluxes for any possible interferences that may have affected the reactivity of the Luminol solution or CrO3 converter over the course of the day (including O3, PAN, etc.), standard curves were performed in the field at each site immediately before, during, and after gas sampling using a known concentration of NO standard gas (Scott-Marrin Inc., Riverside, California).

12. The standard curve was corrected for changes in O2 mixing ratios caused by mixing of scrubbed air with O2-free standard gas, and all chamber fluxes were calculated using the linear fit between instrument output (mV) and standard gas concentrations (ppb) over the range of expected values.

section.title: Estimation of Soil NO Fluxes
section.para: 1. In order to estimate soil NO fluxes from the Phoenix urban ecosystem where ambient NOx is substantial, ‘‘minimum’’ and ‘‘maximum’’ soil NOx flux estimates were calculate based on two different techniques used during different parts of the year when air temperatures were cool (minimum estimate, spring) and warm (maximum estimate, summer).
2. For the minimum flux estimate, soil fluxes from chambers was measured without scrubbing ambient NO entering the chamber in the incoming air stream.

3. In the diel experiment, NO fluxes were calculated as the difference between independent measurements of NOx and NO2 fluxes within the same chamber (measurements of each gas were taken one after the other with the chamber aired out between samples).
4. In the background flux experiment, combined NOx fluxes (NO + NO2) were measured over the course of 6-8 min after the chamber was placed on the ring.
5. NO flux was calculated as the change in NOx concentration between 4 and 8 min of sampling.

6. For the maximum estimate made during the summer, ultrahigh-purity NO-free air was injected into the chamber for 30 s at 2 psi and allowed to vent until initial NO2 concentrations at the soil surface were near zero.
7. Because NOx-free incoming air was introduced to the chamber at a relatively high flow rate, 900-1050 mL min!1, all fluxes were corrected for the dilution of the sample from NOx-free air.
8. Then the statistical analysis was performed.
